previous.name: A Question About the Dimension of Neither Perception Nor Non-Perception

segments.en: “They speak of this thing called the ‘signless immersion of the heart’.
What is the signless immersion of the heart?

segments.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: ‘It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.
This is called the signless immersion of the heart.’

segments.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
segments.en: And so … I was entering and remaining in the signless immersion of the heart.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato nimittānusāri viññāṇaṃ hoti.
segments.en: While I was in that meditation, my consciousness followed after signs.

segments.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

segments.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ pamādo, animitte cetosamādhismiṃ cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, animitte cetosamādhismiṃ cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, animitte cetosamādhismiṃ cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
segments.en: Don’t neglect the signless immersion of the heart, brahmin! Settle your mind in the signless immersion of the heart; unify your mind and immerse it in the signless immersion of the heart.’

segments.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
segments.en: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the signless immersion of the heart.

segments.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
segments.en: So if anyone should be rightly called

segments.pli: ‘satthārānuggahito sāvako mahābhiññataṃ patto’ti, mamaṃ taṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
segments.en: a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sections.title: “They speak of this thing called the ‘signless immersion…

suttaplex.blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the signless immersion was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
